body:
Everything is OK now.

Ready for merge.

Sorry to bother you. I don't have to search for it .
Thank you

Hi, I have tried bucketing, but my case seems not same as words training. Let me put it simply:
here we want to train a very Simple 3-layer MLP like the example below:
''using MXNet
fc1  = mx.FullyConnected(data = data, name=:fc1, num_hidden=128)
act1 = mx.Activation(data = fc1, name=:relu1, act_type=:relu)
fc2  = mx.FullyConnected(data = act1, name=:fc2, num_hidden=64)
act2 = mx.Activation(data = fc2, name=:relu2, act_type=:relu)
fc3  = mx.FullyConnected(data = act2, name=:fc3, num_hidden=10)
mlp  = mx.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc3, name=:softmax)...''
our matrix data is already there, so how to feed it into the neural network? We are beginners of MXNet, so we want to need a simple script to tell us how to feed our own data simply to the network. Thanks a million!
@xlvector Seems the submodules `dmlc-core` and `mshadow` are downgraded. Need to revert these two changes.
@piiswrong
I think the example is good to merge after changing back the submodules since it breaks no API.

@freddycct This is an implementation for the language modelling task **without** Scheduled Sampling(https://papers.nips.cc/paper/5956-scheduled-sampling-for-sequence-prediction-with-recurrent-neural-networks.pdf). The ground truth word rather than the prediction output is used as the input of the next timestamp. Since the outputs are generated without predictions, we can just concatenate predictions from all the timestamps and fit them into a single loss layer.

Oh I see, in that case I have to add the softmaxoutput to each lstm cell. I see, thanks.

BTW, does this mean that mxnet should have a more updated RNN example... If I can code one, I will release it here...
@sxjscience Is this ok now?

check if these 2 help you.
[io_util.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/speech-demo/io_util.py)
[data_iter.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rcnn/rcnn/data_iter.py)
@sxjscience Do you know where the standard data_iter tutorial is? Bucketing is a little hard for beginners but I can't find any better tutorial.
@mli @tqchen
any preview?
no server. try pull it and build?

@tokyolearninng You can try to directly bind the symbol and use low-level APIs (`forward` + `backward`). https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/simple_bind.ipynb and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/adversary/adversary_generation.ipynb are good examples. Also, the first notebook contains example about how to use `NDArrayIter`. You can also load your data into an `NDArrayIter` and call high-level APIs like `fit` for training.
you can add a new website at readthedocs.org for https://github.com/yuweiw823/mxnet e.g. https://readthedocs.org/projects/mxnet-mli/
I think [example/python-howto/data_iter.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/python-howto/data_iter.py) should be renamed. It is so misleading.
@freddycct That's great! You are more than welcome to give an example on that!

1. Yes. I have a refactor version based on module, but not commit yet
2. It is scaling down the gram L2 loss
3. The constant doesn't matter
4. It is using VGG
5. SGD is totally fine. If you adjust the pre-defined hyper-parameters, you will get better result. eg:
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1258974/16136702/af3f85ca-33e1-11e6-871d-6aacb1b6ba7e.png)

Thanks for the awesome reply!

Which hyper-parameters are you adjusting to achieve that result? Just the learning rate, style-weight, and content weight? Or are you including the momentum, etc.?
For this sample, I changed style weight and stop eps. I trained more epochs.

Okay, so your commit should fix 1. and everything else is accounted for. 

Is there somewhere I can read more about how the gram L2 loss is being scaled down? I still don't fully understand what is happening with grad_scale and grad_array.
I think it is skimage bug. I repeat several times, sometimes it happens sometimes not.

grad_scale is the normalization factor based on the gram matrix. Then we use weight and these scale to calculation make top gradient, store in grad_array. If replace that with LinearRegressionOutput, the grad_array value will be grad_scale.
Can't it work exactly like cuDNN layers, where you can disable/enable DAAL at compile-time?
I think @sbodenstein is right that it will work exactly like cuDNN layers. We can first add it as a optional plugin
I'm sorry, but I must be missing something. How is the inverse of (channels**2 \* img_height \* img_width)  the gradient?
Yes. But it will make the operator folder size explode.
that is why it can be added as an optional plugin first, so it does not need to be coupled with the current project

So I think we may do a refactor on organization of operators in summer:
We need support these operator as plugin:
- Pure C++/CUDA Kernel/CuDNN/DAAL
- MShadow/Eigen
- OpenCL/Whatever 

The third may involve storage change and need more discussion, and the first & second seems need to make `.cc`, `.cu` and `.h` file lie in different place. 

Besides I think another target is: if one cuda op is missing but there is cpu op, we can insert a copy op in graph and call cpu op then copy back, rather than implement everything.  

These are very early thoughts and need to be investigated further,

You network has problem when infering its input output shapes, so please double check to make sure their dimensions and sizes are right.

```
class SequenceIter(mx.io.DataIter):
    # self.provide_data is an array of tuples and that tuple is (data_name, data_shape)
    # self.provide_label is an array of tuples and that tuple is (label_name, label_shape)

    def __init__(self, data, init_states):
        super(SequenceIter, self).__init__() # calling DataIter.__init__()

        self.data = data

        # get the dimensions of the data
        shape = int(data[0].size)
        num_inputs = len(data)

        self.label = data[1:] + [mx.nd.zeros(shape)]

        provide_data  = []
        provide_label = []

        for i,x in enumerate(data):
            provide_data.append( ('data/%d' % i, (1, int(x.size))) )
            provide_label.append( ('label/%d' % i, (1, int(x.size))) )

        self.provide_data  = provide_data + init_states
        self.provide_label = provide_label
```
